passage.text: Calcium-mediated transductive systems and functionally active gap junctions in astrocyte-like GL15 cells
Ultimately, findings of this study support the use of the GL15 cell line as an in vitro astrocyte model for studying physiological features of glial cells at different stages of differentiation.

Olfaction is a crucial neurosensory activity in mammals that involves analyzing the chemical environment surrounding them. The first step in identifying scents is the interaction between an odorant and its receptors, which are located at the surface of cilia in the olfactory area. Seven-transmembrane ORs were identified in 1991 as the largest family of G-protein-coupled receptor (OR) proteins, representing classical OR categories from Class I or A. Each molecule recognizes multiple scented or other active motifs.

These studies suggest that PP5 plays a role in controlling nucleocytoplasmic shuttling and that the suppression of pythonic regulatory protein 5 (PP5) leads to nuclear accumulation of highly reactive GRs without the presence of any hormone. This implies that there is likely more nuclear activity associated with the increase in generative gene expression (GR)-induced transcriptional activity after ISIS 15534 induced translation from Greek, suggesting that this may be due to either nuclear upregulation or export of genetically modified genes.
